pullRequest.body:
Prove that the angle between two complex numbers is the absolute value of the argument of their quotient.

From LeanAPAP

---

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

This all seems good to me, though this is the first Mathlib PR I've reviewed (I have of course reviewed a lot of other code of other types).

I'll click "approve" with hesitations as a result, since my sense is this only signals something and doesn't give any actual merging permissions.

However, it was mentioned in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Roughly.2C.20Lipschitzness.20of.20the.20inverse.20of.20.60exp.20.28t.20*.20I.29.60/near/422101495 that this PR contained the result I needed about exp, but I don't see it.  Is that because it converts the complex theory into angles, and the result was already there for angles?

This all seems good to me, though this is the first Mathlib PR I've reviewed (I have of course reviewed a lot of other code of other types).

I'll click "approve" with hesitations as a result, since my sense is this only signals something and doesn't give any actual merging permissions.

However, it was mentioned in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Roughly.2C.20Lipschitzness.20of.20the.20inverse.20of.20.60exp.20.28t.20*.20I.29.60/near/422101495 that this PR contained the result I needed about exp, but I don't see it.  Is that because it converts the complex theory into angles, and the result was already there for angles?

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Should we be using `euclidean_geometry.angle` somehow here?
I'm not sure that `arcLength` is a good name. For me, "arclength" means "arclength of a curve".

It is definitely referred to as "arc-length" in the additive combinatorics literature when `x` and `y` are unit complex numbers. However as Eric points out my new definition is a special case of `InneProductGeometry.angle`, so this is moot.

I will record here that my definition actually differed from `InnerProductGeometry.angle` in that it had junk value `0` when `x` or `y` is zero while `InnerProductGeometry.angle` has junk value `Ï / 2`. It turns out that I'm wrong and Joseph Myers is right, because his junk value means that the triangle inequality for the angle is true (but not yet proved) even if one of the three points is `0`.

For points on the unit circle, it is the arc length of the shortest arc of the unit circle that joins the points. I think that we should add a type (not a `Subtype`) for a sphere and use this metric there (at least in the case of an inner product space). However, for `x = 2` and `y = 3 * I`, it has nothing to do with arc length of a curve.

Yes, I wrote all of this in my original PR description, but I edited it out since it's now irrelevant.

Note that we do not have the triangle inequality for `angle`, so we currently can't prove `MetricSpace unitSphere`.
Could you please adjust the PR title?
I think it's worth adding a docstring reminding the reader why this is not true when `x` or `y` is 0.
This no longer exists, right?
This lemma feels contrived to me, as all lemmas with `(hxy : x = ..)` do. ~~To make it worthwhile, is it true as an `iff`?~~

I think this lemma deserves to exist since the entire point of `arccos` is that it's the inverse of `cos`. In my case, I would have to do
```lean
lemma angle_eq_abs_arg (hx : x â  0) (hy : y â  0) : angle x y = |(x / y).arg| := by
  suffices : âªx, yâ«_â / (âxâ * âyâ) = Real.cos |arg (x / y)|
  Â· rw [angle, this, Real.arccos_cos (abs_nonneg _) (abs_arg_le_pi _)]
  rw [Real.cos_abs , Complex.cos_arg (div_ne_zero hx hy)]
  have := (map_ne_zero Complex.abs).2 hx
  have := (map_ne_zero Complex.abs).2 hy
  simp [div_eq_mul_inv, Complex.normSq_eq_norm_sq]
  field_simp
  ring
```
which is IMO much less natural and forces me to write the LHS and RHS a second time.
Note that backticks on Github need ` ```lean `
Note that you can edit my comments.
@eric-wieser what do you think here?
Could you please add a version saying `(fun Î¸ â¦ exp (Î¸ * I)) '' Set.Ioc (-Ï) Ï = Metric.sphere 0 1`? BTW, this should be a general fact about `Periodic` functions (image = range).
I agree that it should be there in greater generality, but I found the glue painful to write. For now, I've left a TODO.
Please add `@[deprecated] alias`es.
Do you think it makes sense to prove things about `oangle` too? Fine to leave to a later PR.
Added a todo

```suggestion
@[deprecated] alias angle_eq_of_ne := angle_self_of_ne
```
Errant space before the comma, I think.
I was told nonterminal `simp`s are frowned above, as opposed to `simp only`s generated by `simp?`.  This case seems reasonable though given the robustness of the remaining tactics.
Yes, by "nonterminal simp" we mean "simp before a rigid tactic like `exact`, `apply` or `refine`". But `field_simp` and `ring` are definitely not rigid.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Angle between complex numbers
